docs.lead_paragraph: Though Neil LaBute's ''Bash: Latter-Day Plays'' wasn't written originally for television, it translates so well it could have been. The intimacy of this trilogy of one-act monologues, designed as sparely as a SoHo dress store, seems made for television, and not just because one of the actors is Ally McBeal (a k a Calista Flockhart). The characters spill their secrets in a confessional rush, like guests on a talk show. But the familiarity is deceptive, which simply adds another layer to Mr. LaBute's insistent investigation of the nastiness lurking beneath the most placid exteriors. As a filmmaker (''In the Company of Men'') and a playwright, he specializes in exhuming the worm within. Evil isn't always interesting, he insists. It exists in the blandest of men and women. When you've stepped into Mr. LaBute's fantasy neighborhood, you'd better watch out for the apple-cheeked boy next door. He might go berserk and kill you.

headline.main: It's Evil, And Often It's Not So Banal

docs.abstract: Julie Salamon reviews Neil LaBute's Bash: Latter-Day Plays, trilogy of one-act monologues being shown on Showtime; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE math is simple and impressive. The School of the Holy Child here has 19 interscholastic high school sports teams at the varsity or junior varsity level. It has 200 girls in its high school grades. ''Yes,'' said Cathi Wasilik, the director of athletics at the all-girl Catholic school, ''most of our girls play two or more varsity sports. We think it's healthy.''

headline.main: A School Where Girls Learn the Value of Sports

docs.abstract: Article on School of Holy Child in Harrison, NY, which places important emphasis on girls' participation in team sports and which has 19 interscholastic high school sports team at varsity or junior varsity level; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The moment the star-crossed title characters in Paul Morrison's somber love story ''Solomon and Gaenor'' set eyes on each other, your heart sinks. It is immediately obvious there is nowhere for these young lovers to travel but down an awfully familiar path from clandestine ecstasy to pariahhood to tragedy that could take any of three final twists, all equally predictable. Surrendering yourself to this well-acted film is never a question of wondering when the last shoe will drop, but one of how much you'll allow yourself to identify with its likable but foolish lovers, who break the strict social rules of their claustrophobically dingy community and pay the usual price. That community is an impoverished Welsh coal mining village in 1911. Solomon (Ioan Gruffudd) is the eldest son in a devout Orthodox Jewish family that has recently migrated to Wales from Russia and has set up a pawnshop that doubles as a drapery business. One of Solomon's tasks is to go from door to door of the miners' cottages across the hill, peddling swatches of cloth that can be made into dresses. One day he stops at the door of Gaenor's strict, churchgoing family. She answers his knock, and a spark is lighted.

headline.main: He Was Only a Fabric Peddler, but He Sure Sold Her a Bill of Goods

docs.lead_paragraph: Harel Levy had lost two previous times to James Blake, but he is no longer the same Harel Levy. Just ask James Blake. ''When I last played him about a year ago, he wasn't doing it at this level,'' Blake said yesterday after Levy defeated him, 7-5, 6-2, in the United States Open qualifying to earn a berth in the main draw. Levy, a 22-year-old Israeli, qualified for the main draw because Mariano Zabaleta, Nicolas Escude and Andrei Medvedev pulled out. That leaves an additional three openings for so-called lucky losers, the top-ranked qualifiers who lose in the third round but get in the draw because of other withdrawals. As the top-seeded qualifier, Levy automatically gets in even if he loses his third-round qualifying match today. Levy, who had been ranked No. 144, emerged recently to reach the final of a major tournament in Toronto. He is now ranked 70th. About 1,500 spectators nearly packed the Court 7 grandstand of the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park to watch Levy finish off Blake with a hard serve. BALCELLS FALLS: Juan Balcells was celebrated by Spain when he and Alex Corretja beat Todd Martin and Chris Woodruff in doubles to clinch the Davis Cup semifinal against the United States in July. Yesterday on Court 8, Balcells was just another journeyman. To put a polite spin on what a certain Davis Cup coach asked: Who the heck is Juan Balcells? ''I'm not a hero and I don't usually lose in the first round of a qualifier,'' Balcells said after falling to Frantisek Cermak, 4-6, 7-6 (6), 3-6. Balcells earned his five sets of fame when John McEnroe made light of him before last month's Davis Cup tie between the United States and Spain. Balcells answered with a gritty performance in doubles, then upset Jan-Michael Gambill in singles to give Spain a 5-0 sweep. Days later, the 111th-ranked Balcells lost to Christian Ruud, 6-2, 6-2, in the first round of a tournament at Kitzbuhel, Austria, and has not played since. LUCIC IS ALMOST IN: Mirjana Lucic, a Wimbledon semifinalist last year who dipped from 32nd to 203rd in the rankings, is one victory from the United States Open after defeating Evelyn Fauth, 6-2, 3-6, 6-1. It was a rare second straight triumph for Lucic, who was eliminated in the first round of six straight tournaments at one point this season. PREGNANT PLAYER LOSES: Lindsay Lee-Waters, nearly five months pregnant and almost four years removed from when she was ranked 36th, was tied at 3-3 in the deciding set against Na Li before leg cramps set in. Lee-Waters did not win a game from then on, and Li prevailed by 7-5, 4-6, 6-3. Lee-Waters said her pregnancy had a little effect, but I just wasn't accurate enough with my shots. RON DICKER

docs.lead_paragraph: A rotator-cuff injury once knocked out Lindsay Lee-Waters at the height of her career. She isn't about to let being nearly five months pregnant stop her. Lee-Waters, 23, is due to deliver a girl in early January, but she is squeezing in one last tournament. She was to have played Na Li yesterday in the first round of the United States Open qualifying, but rain washed away her match and several others at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Lee-Waters will play the match today, needing three rounds to advance to the Open, which begins Monday.

headline.main: Having Extra Incentive to Win a Qualifying Spot

docs.abstract: Lindsay Lee-Waters, who is expecting baby in Jan, is trying to qualify for US Open tennis tournament; photo (M)
